top_comment.text:
Let's all agree that #TrickleDownEconomics never worked and grab that

top_comment.author: Robbie Adams

comments.text:
Even Ben Stien stipulated this on the very FOX NEWS

Ben Stein Stuns Fox news about Mitt Romney tax cut

We Must Raise Taxes On The Rich Says Ben Stein
comments.author: Robbie Adams

comments.text:
Just study the last 50 years. You’ll see that there’s NO such predictable 
correlation between the top tax rate and economic growth factors such as 
GDP, wage and job growth. In fact, contrary to what many supporters for 
Trickle Down Economics suggests, some of the United States biggest economic 
gains took place during a *70%* and *91%* top tax rate and the some of the 
greatest periods of stagnation occurred during the lowest top tax rate. I 
have so much data on this. 
Simple math numbers showing this. The real prosperous for this were the 
wealthy and corporations...that took those savings and tax cuts and 
invested it mostly overseas...
comments.author: Robbie Adams

comments.text:
LOL...Never worked in the 1980's either. Oh my. I have so much 
documentation on this from various sources  RIGHT, LEFT, LEFT OF CENTER, 
RIGHT OF CENTER up the ying yang  that i can fill my local Library. I 
actually did a thesis paper on this some years ago. LOL Never worked the 
way they tried to sell it. Never did. There is so much data on this its 
almost blinding. 
So many factors OTHER then Trickle Down economics also contributed to that 
prosperous era. Trickle Down Economics was not the main contributor at all. 
Regardless, it's difficult to say whether trickle-down economics was the 
only reason for the prosperity during the 1980's because of Ronald Reagan's 
over spending. While Reagan cut taxes, he also increased government 
spending by 2.5% a year. Reagan nearly tripled the Federal debt, which went 
from $997 billion in 1981 to $2.85 trillion in 1989. He also increased the 
size of the Government. Which by today's GOP standards would have never 
seen him leading the party as the GOP keeps stating smaller government and 
NO over sending causing Federal Debt. Ya..Right
Moreover, this spending went primarily to defense, in support of Reagan's 
successful efforts to end the Cold War and bring down the Soviet Union. 
Therefore, trickle-down economics was never really tested, since government 
spending is also a spur to economic growth as you know.
The main demographics that prospered from this form of "Supply Side 
Economics" were the rich and wealthy. There is so much documentation and 
proof on this it's STAGGERING. The only people left BELIEVING it worked are 
the very ones who PROFITED fully from it. 

*"The Republican Party has totally abdicated its job in our democracy, 
which is to act as the guardian of fiscal discipline and responsibility. 
They're on an anti-tax jihad -- one that benefits the prosperous classes."*
That was stated by David Stockman
He also goes on to state how Trickle Down Economics did not work. The very 
man who was Ronald Reagan's Director of the Office of Management and Budget 
who orchestrated Trickle Down Economics for that Administration.

http://nomadicpolitics.blogspot.ca/2012/10/the-incredible-hoax-of-reaganomics_4.html

http://billmoyers.com/content/david-stockman-on-the-folly-of-anti-tax-crusades/

http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2010/11/07/reagan-budget-chief-slams-gop-taxes/

http://rationalrevolution.net/war/trickle_down.htm

http://www.faireconomy.org/research/TrickleDown.html


*“Triumph of Politics: Why the Reagan Revolution Failed.”  The reason: no 
one at the time, Republican or Democrat, was willing to cut spending, and 
if you cut taxes, you must cut spending. Cutting taxes for the rich does 
not increase government income.*
-David Stokman

The theory is sound  It's implementation because of corporate greed killed 
its success.
comments.author: Robbie Adams

comments.text: The 80s never happened... Lol
comments.author: Trey Motes

top_comment.text:
This is nonsense.  If the middle class didn't have money, how did the GDP 
grow so much?  If the middle class represents the class with the most 
"demand", how did it grow so much?  Kind of defeats the argument right 
there!  You could argue the weak dollar provided GDP growth through trade 
or inflation.  Irrespective of these things, the problem is, regardless of 
what this guy is saying, what it really boils down to is just . . . one . . 
. thing . . . he and others want to tax the rich more.  Class envy at its 
finest.  "Get even with'm."   That's it.﻿

comments.author: Panda God

top_comment.text:
There is no such thing as 'trickle down economics', there is no economist 
who advocates it because the whole term is a made up leftist farce. I 
cannot believe TYT are so stupid as to actually make a video on the topic 
that as an economic theory is non existent.

The 'trickle down' idiocy is simply an incorrectly applied slang term for 
Reagan's 'Supply Side' economic policies.


Just in case people think I am making this stuff up:
http://www.columbian.com/news/2014/jan/07/left-uses-trickle-down-boogeyman-as-a-scare-tactic/
﻿
top_comment.author: Piotr Nowacki

comments.text:
+Geoff Roach
As soon as you reject the morality of self-interest and embrace the 
morality of sacrifice you have rejected the idea that your life belongs to 
you which is the meaning of Capitalism. Any anti-Capitalist system is going 
to be trickle down because if your life doesn't belong to you then neither 
does any product of your life.
comments.author: MrApplewine

comments.text:
+MrApplewine No, USSR was a dictatorship, you keep confusing the two when 
in fact, there's never really been a communist country. If you're really 
believing it was communist, then you do not truly understand communism. In 
order for communism to work, there can be no government, and everyone is 
equal. This means no one person rules over the rest. As for Socialism, the 
closest we have to socialist countries are 9 of the top 10 happiest 
countries on this planet, Switzerland, Australia, new Zealand, Canada, 
Sweden, etc. These are socialist countries, all of whom do better then the 
United States. Also, to compare Socialism to Communism is idiotic, because 
they're again two completely different systems. So I will end it here, you 
can keep spouting nonsense and keep trying to beat a dead horse with your 
idiotic idea of the different parties without understanding them, or do the 
full research like I have to understand what each system is.
comments.author: Geoff Roach

comments.text:
+Mike Kelley
Remember, trickle down is communism/socialism authoritarianism, not 
Capitalism. Capitalism you keep your money. It isn't taken from you buy the 
people in charge and fed back in small drops in order to somehow be more 
efficient than if you spent it yourself. Capitalism is the anti-trickle 
down system.
comments.author: MrApplewine

comments.text:
Reagan never used the term Trickle Down. People often argue against it but 
no one has ever advocated it.
comments.author: Mike Kelley

comments.text:

of degree on the path to the same incremental end result.
comments.author: MrApplewine

comments.text:
+MrApplewine Then that's not communism is it? That's a dictatorship. In 
reality, Communism cannot work, because it will quickly be controlled by 
one or a select group of people (hey, much like what capitalism is doing 
now a days, go figure). Everything you just said is what the United States 
capitalism is doing right now. If you're not wealthy (normally through 
inheritance) or you don't take orders from the rich, you are probably poor 
(since the middle class is almost none existent in this day and age and the 
top 0.1% control more wealth then the bottom 40% combined. Also yes, we 
don't use trickle down economics, we pretend to as the government keeps 
cutting taxes for the extremely wealthy, being told that the wealthy will 
create more jobs and thus give those benieth them more money. Sadly, this 
is a farce as the last time we saw this was before Reagan when Ford was the 
biggest company in the US. It's thanks to Reagan's policies that screwed p 
this country. 

Also like how you didn't even comment on my explination of Socialism, you 
went straight to communism, which I again find funny since there's never 
been a true communist country since no country can truly be communist 
unless all matters of greed, want, and desire are removed from the human 
equation.

comments.author: tw25rw

comments.text:
+tw25rw Yes, you can group it as the anti-capitalists. Or even more broadly 
as the the anti-objectives. The left and right reject the objective 
alternative in philosophy as well as the morality of selfishness for which 
the principle of individual rights is based. Instead we have the intrinsic 
religious sacrificial philosophy of the right and the secularized 
subjective sacrificial philosophy of the left. The Objective alternative as 
well as a morality of the individual not based on sacrifice is always 
marginalized as a valid option. This has been the plight of humanity for 
thousands of years and will not be overcome easily. Humans have so much 
potential and are suffering when we could be living more and flourishing 
with a morality that continues the traditions of Aristotle and the 
objective use of reason that was discovered in ancient Greece. Things took 
a major down-turn with the invention of Christianity and then later the 
invention of secularized collectivism / mysticism / religion by 
philosophers in Europe like Kant, Hegel and Marx. Perhaps the hardest 
lesson for humanity is to learn to believe in themselves and understand 
what that means in a moral sense.
comments.author: MrApplewine

LEFT/COMMUNISTS/ANTI-CAPITALISTS BLAH BLAH BLAH. Happy you have a convert?

comments.text:

comments.author: MrApplewine

comments.text:
+MrApplewine oh, i wasnt using trickle down as a means to insult 
capitalism, theres other reasons for that, and you obviously know nothing 
of socialism or comunism if you believe they use trickle down, the true 
aspects of socialism is that the means of production is controlled by the 
people and government, but the government is also controlled by the people, 
not the rich, much like the government our founding fathers were apart of. 
Communism is where everything, production and ownership is equally 
controlled by the masses, this is the one everyone fears, yets slaps 
socialism on it when socialism is capitalism for the masses, not just the 
few. You can still become wealthy in socialism, but your wealth will be 
regulated better, to which it wont bloat like how the top 0.1% are 
currently.
comments.author: Geoff Roach

top_comment.text:
This is nonsense. Where do the rich put their money? (sure, many put their 
money into off shore accounts so their money doesn't get raped by the 
government) But for the most part, they'd put their money into American 
banks if there was an incentive. What do you think happens to that money? 
Do you think it just collects cobwebs? NO. The poor and middle class take 
out loans which they use to invest and grow their money.﻿
top_comment.author: Ryan Ferretti

comments.text:
Funny you say that the middle class uses that to invest considering that 
90% of the American stock market is owned by the top 10% of Americans. 
While everyone was freaking out about 3-5% tax increase for the rich, the 
government spent $1.4 trillion in mortgage-backed securities all of which 
goes to wall-street. Compound this with the current interest rates and the 
only people benefiting are the top 10% who own the stock-market.

Everybody is too focused on tax-cuts, when in reality the current 
government economic plan is to pretty much stimulate the stock market. If 
anyone does the math, it's pretty simple to see that the people who benefit 
the most from this are people who own stock. "Trickle down economics" 
indeed.
comments.author: Franco Lorenzo Buhay

comments.text:
+Duck Man the rich hoard money for one reason the "Great stagnation" as of 
right now unlike in old fashion times  there is great speculation over what 
the next great investment of the future is. there have been no new real 
innovations that have changed american life like it was done back in the 
early 1900/ late 1800's during the "industrial revolution" where the 
economy was great for everyone same reason why the united states was so 
prosperous during the the 1990's because of innovation like the cell phone 
and Internet which then really gives incentives to  big businesses to go 
invest their money instead of let it sit in banks( which as of right now 
business are actually losing money by just sittig on it because of low 
interest rates) (when interest rates are low its an indication that their 
is economic stagnation because its ENCOURAGING people to take out loans 
when they dont want to - same reason why its cheap(low interest) to buy a 
house after the 2008)

whats my point? great innovation is what creates economic growth. the 
economy is too dynamic and complex to be solved just by a formula if that 
was the case we would have figured it out already a long time ago. 
"trickle down" economics works when theirs innovation but when there not we 
should not  resort having a centralized group (gov) create artificial 
growth that is not sustainable.
comments.author: Richard Thomas

comments.text:

comments.author: tw25rw

comments.text:
+William Broderick The "nothing to see here, move along" argument you seem 
intent on making isn't very good. Difference of opinion maybe, but "wild

comments.author: yxrf1xg0

comments.text:
+Wade MacMorrighan Hoard their cash?  Where?  In their mattress?  No.  
Likely it's in stocks, bonds, savings, mutual funds and other investments.  
Guess what the money does when in it's in those accounts?  It gets invested 
and loaned out in the trillions each year.
comments.author: William Broderick

comments.text:
Nonsense? I think not. It's common sense is more like it. What you just 
said is true but is also the reason why the middle class is in trouble and 
is on their way to becoming the poor class. Obviously if people are always 
having to take loans which seems to be the case more than ever. Interest 
has to be paid on those loans making the rich richer and obviously the 
middle class poorer and one can only afford so much debt until they can't 
spend anymore. and once they can spend anymore then the economy suffers and 
those middle class people than become part of the poor class. Do you see 
how this is not a good cycle?

 If the middle class gets breaks large corporations/rich will obviously 
benefit because people will be out buying their products, and services 
which is good for their(rich) pocket book but also means that these 
corporations will have to higher more people and maybe even pay a decent 
wage to their employees since they will have extra revenue. So we all 
benefit. As for the banks...People are always going to need loans for big 
purchases such as cars and houses so they will still get lots of interest 
and they will probably make out better in the end because they won't have 
so many people defaulting on their mortgage/loans.

Bottom line is "Trickle down" is just greedy and obviously hasn't worked 
for us. I'm no specialist in economics by any means but it just seems like 
common sense to me.
comments.author: 0verload

comments.text:
Why should their be an incentive. Its sad they worship money so much, that 
they put it wear it can accumulate more.
comments.author: The Illuminated One

comments.text:
Then you are required to pay the banks interest for the loans which can be 
a debt sentence if you're poor enough, and the interest gets sent to the 
greedy rich ass bank owners who gamble with that money as well. So in the 
end we all lose.
comments.author: Echonova21

comments.text:
Actually, what the wealthy precisely do with their money has been studied 
by Economists as we were emerging from the Great Recession, and the 
conclusion was that the Wealthy--very literally--don't do ANYTHING with 
their money (least of all creating jobs!).  Instead, the studies 
overwhelmingly found, they sit on it and rather than spend one copper cent 
of it!  So yes, as a matter of fact, study-after-study DID find that this 
enormous wealth that is being generated DOES just, in your words, "collect 
cobwebs".  Presumably, this is because there are no policies in place 
encouraging them to spend instead of horde their cash.
comments.author: Wade MacMorrighan

comments.text:
I wonder if you know about the wealth speculation that has increased in the 
past 30 years. Gross investment in the US on fixed assets which shows 
whether businesses are investing into infrastructure and machinery is only 
11% according to CIA factbook. America also has some of the lowest saving 
rates  in the world of around 12.5%. The idea that people put their money 
in banks and the banks invest into the economy is very old fashioned
comments.author: Duck Man
